learning_outcomes.description: Read and critically analyse current scientific literature related to the area of the research project.
Identify research questions, investigate appropriate methodology and plan experiments to address these questions.
Perform practical and/or theoretical experimental work, under the guidance of an experienced supervisor.
Record the planning and outcome of experiments accurately and at a level that is both appropriate and expected in modern day scientific research.
Write a substantial report based on your scientific investigation in a format suitable for a biomedical science audience.
Critically discuss scientific data in the context of existing literature, draw conclusions from such discussions and suggest further experiments.
Present the outcomes of a scientific project and its significance to both expert and non-expert audiences, accurately and appropriately.

assessments.task_description:
• A report comprised of a literature review relevant to the student's area of research, a statement of hypotheses and aims and a description of the proposed research plan. Students should also clearly outline the significance of their proposed research. Please consult your Honours Handbook for further information.
  • This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
  • As this assessment is marked by two or more examiners and a post-marking moderation process is applied, re-marks are not permitted as per the Assessment Procedure (clause 114).
assessments.submission_guidelines: An electronic copy of your assignment in BOTH Word and PDF format must be submitted through the Turnitin link on the course Blackboard website by the assessment due date.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to organise and attend a semi-formal progress meeting with members of their supervisory team prior to, or during, the first teaching week of their second semester.

Ahead of this meeting, students must prepare a concise progress update using the PowerPoint template provided via Blackboard. This presentation should clearly summarise project aims, work completed to date, preliminary findings (where applicable), challenges encountered, and a proposed plan for the next phase of the project.

During the meeting, students are expected to actively contribute to discussion, demonstrate depth of understanding of their project, and respond thoughtfully to feedback and questions from supervisors.

At the conclusion of the meeting, the student and supervisory team fill out a Meeting Record that captures key discussion points, agreed actions, timelines and any revisions to project direction. This table is to be included in your ppt file.

If you or your supervisor have concerns that your project cannot be completed satisfactorily with remaining time and resources, please schedule a discussion with course co-ordinators for advice.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The completed presentation, coverted to PDF, is to be posted to the course Blackboard site by the end of teaching week 1 of your second semester.
